rev.comment: made clear that UTI is only for Apple bundles
rev.diff:
Line 5: Line 5:
A bundle usually contains one file representing executable code, and files that represent resources such as [[Interface Builder#Nib files|nibs]], images, sounds, and other media. On some other systems, such as [[Microsoft Windows]], these resources are usually included directly in the executable file itself at compile time. On older Macintoshes, a similar technique is used, where additional [[metadata]] can be added to a file's [[resource fork]]. Beginning with the Mac OS X, the [[NEXTSTEP]] concept of bundles was adopted for this purpose, in order to ease problems associated with organizing resources by using a simpler structure of [[hierarchical]] directories rather than the resource fork. In an attempt to reduce the risk of accidental tampering, most types of bundles are, in the [[Finder (software)|Finder]], normally treated as though they were ordinary files on the system, with no visible structure; directories treated in that fashion are called "[[Package (Mac OS X)|packages]]".
A bundle usually contains one file representing executable code, and files that represent resources such as [[Interface Builder#Nib files|nibs]], images, sounds, and other media. On some other systems, such as [[Microsoft Windows]], these resources are usually included directly in the executable file itself at compile time. On older Macintoshes, a similar technique is used, where additional [[metadata]] can be added to a file's [[resource fork]]. Beginning with the Mac OS X, the [[NEXTSTEP]] concept of bundles was adopted for this purpose, in order to ease problems associated with organizing resources by using a simpler structure of [[hierarchical]] directories rather than the resource fork. In an attempt to reduce the risk of accidental tampering, most types of bundles are, in the [[Finder (software)|Finder]], normally treated as though they were ordinary files on the system, with no visible structure; directories treated in that fashion are called "[[Package (Mac OS X)|packages]]".
â
The [[Uniform Type Identifier]] (UTI) for a bundle is <tt>com.apple.bundle</tt>.<ref>{{cite web|title=System-Declared Uniform Type Identifiers|work=Uniform Type Identifiers Reference|url=http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Miscellaneous/Reference/UTIRef/Articles/System-DeclaredUniformTypeIdentifiers.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009259-SW1|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref>
+
The [[Uniform Type Identifier]] (UTI) for an Apple bundle is <tt>com.apple.bundle</tt>.<ref>{{cite web|title=System-Declared Uniform Type Identifiers|work=Uniform Type Identifiers Reference|url=http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Miscellaneous/Reference/UTIRef/Articles/System-DeclaredUniformTypeIdentifiers.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009259-SW1|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|accessdate=2011-03-16}}</ref>
